title: A Case For Gucci Crocodile Skin Bags ($52,000 A Piece)
author: Unknown
summary: The exotic skin trade is widely considered unethical due to animal cruelty. However, for some endangered reptile species, their commercial value in the luxury market, like crocodile skin bags, may paradoxically be their best chance for survival and conservation, a model proven successful with the Australian Saltwater Crocodile.

sections.heading: The Unethical Truth of the Exotic Skin Trade
sections.content: The exotic skin trading business is unethical. This isn’t a surprising truth. In pursuit of these “Luxury goods”, these animals are abused and slaughtered only for their skin. In 2024, World Animal Protection found that an estimated 5.5 billion animals are farmed annually for use in fashion, traditional medicine, and entertainment.

image.caption: (CBS News, Taken by PETA undercover reporter)

sections.heading: Brutal Harvesting Processes
sections.content:
Pythons are bashed with hammers, impaled on hooks and skinned alive to provide skins used by Italian luxury brand Gucci to craft handbags, shoes and belts that sell for hundreds if not thousands of dollars.

CBS, Kate Gibson, 2024

sections.heading: Conservation vs. Cruelty: The Paradox
sections.content:
Although some stores have banned the sale of products which use the skins of reptiles including lizards, snakes, and alligators likely due to their cruel harvesting processes and concern for protecting endangered species, a ban of reptile skin use could only help with one of these concerns- and actively harm the other.

There are many reptile species that are endangered, yet highly sought after for their unique luxury skins. Although opponents of reptile skin farming may be trying to preserve reptile species by reducing the amount killed for their skin, the crocodile skin’s appearance at London Fashion week might be the only way it can be conserved.

image.caption: (New York Post, Taken by PETA undercover reporter)

sections.heading: Economic Incentive as a Conservation Tool
sections.content:
Although reptiles are often keystone species in many ecosystems, they are very rarely appreciated for this use. Many local communities find reptiles intolerable…that is, unless they have commercial value.

In Australia, the regulation and legalization of the hunting of the once endangered Saltwater Crocodile led to a miraculous recovery of its population. Similar cases of people supporting the reptile population, not in spite of but because of its monetary value have been exhibited from the US, to Peru, to Papua New Guinea.

If given a facet, local populations are encouraged not just to tolerate local reptiles, but support their recovery. If there is money to be made in the species’ ability to thrive, then the species will always survive.

So maybe if we want to help the planet, we in fact should buy into these thousand dollar overpriced endangered python belts.

image.caption: (Roadsandkingdoms.com)

sections.heading: Addressing Welfare Concerns
sections.content:
But what about the reptiles?

Although reptile skin farming may be good for the ecosystem, it is by no means ethical. The reptiles are often starved and killed in ways that preserve the skin, but are literal torture for the animals.

That is why organizations like the Python Conservation Partnership (PCP) were formed. Although it doesn’t insist that the reptile trade should be abandoned, it has a mission to reduce abuse and cruelty in these python farms and “[improve] sustainability, transparency, animal welfare and local livelihoods for the python skin trade.”

title: The Other Amazon: Illegal Reptile Trade and Local Livelihoods
author: Unknown
summary: While the modern Amazon is a retailer, the other Amazon in Brazil is home to an illegal reptile trade. These markets are often condemned, but they exist for complex reasons, including traditional medicine and as a crucial natural resource for local communities. Cracking down on the trade without providing alternatives could lead to the greater ecological harm of deforestation.

sections.content:
Apparently, you can get anything on Amazon these days. Jeans, toothpaste, new ink for your printer, a 4 five foot radius burrito blanket…for those who needed one. There are some things you can’t find on Amazon, however. That’s because they would be illegal.

But maybe if you look in a different Amazon, one in the center of Brazil, you can find an illegal reptile trade which might suit your needs.

image.caption: (New Scientist, Yellow Footed Tortoises for sale)

sections.heading: The Origin of the Markets
sections.content: Illegal animal trading markets are often frowned on as barbarous, unethical, and theorized to be what started Covid-19 all the way in Wuhan, China. But let’s look at why these markets exist.

sections.heading: Traditional and Medicinal Uses
sections.content:
One of the things you can find in these markets is snake oil. In the United States, the term “Snake Oil” is often used to represent deceptive marketing, a salesman who claims that a certain concoction can cure everything when really it’s a fraud.

However, snake oil originated from Chinese traditional medicine. Originally harvested from peeling off the snake’s body while cutting open the belly, it was used as an anti-inflammatory and still is used as a supplement, likely for its high fat content.

Thus, some reptile trade in amazon rainforest is used for medicinal purposes.

Snake oil is not illegal, however the use of other parts of the snake is. But although it is illegal to make and sell snake venom without a license in most countries, this is likely not due to reptile protection and instead due to concern for human use.

sections.heading: The Commerce of Alligator and Reptile Parts
sections.content:
Another item you can find is alligator body parts. Snout, skin, legs, tail, and all. Oftentimes they are sold for meat, skin, or medicinal properties. Although this could sometimes be illegal, the ecological police patrolling these markets often don’t care.

The World Wildlife Fund (WWF) reports that although a lot of these animals are trapped initially by locals, and some are sold as meat products or pets for locals, many also collaborate with international traffickers, from places like Europe, North America, and Asia. The people higher up in this trade make the largest profits.

image.caption: (Mario Tama, Amazon Rainforest)

sections.heading: Local Livelihoods and Conservation Trade-offs
sections.content:
In Brazil, it is legal for the indigenous population to hunt and consume endangered and protected animals. What is illegal is the sale of them.

Although it may seem like the best solution is to crack down on these markets and reduce illegal sale of endangered species, it is not that simple. For the community living in the Amazon rainforest, the rainforest is their natural resource; it is how they make money.

In other places in the world we can look down on the sale of endangered reptiles, but that is because we have other options for making money. In order to have something else to produce, many of these communities would have to deforest the surrounding area, something which is arguably much worse for these endangered reptile populations.

image.caption: (IWT Challenge Fund, Wildlife Trade in Amazonian Peru)

title: Beyond the Bite: The Surprising Intelligence of Saltwater Crocodiles
author: Unknown
summary: Saltwater crocodiles, often feared for their power, speed, and lethal bite (3,700 psi), are one of the world's most misunderstood reptiles. Beyond their deadly predatory nature and incredible adaptations for both water and land, recent research suggests they possess complex social systems, advanced communication, and a surprising level of intelligence, challenging their reputation as mere killing machines.

sections.heading: The Most Terrifying Reptile
sections.content:
Saltwater crocodiles are likely one of the most terrifying reptiles in the animal kingdom. Aside from their supernatural speed, ability to thrive in both salt and fresh water, ability to climb and bite with a force of 3,700 psi on average, crocodiles are also incredibly smart and perceptive.

In humans, saltwater crocodiles are reported to be the cause of at least a thousand deaths as of 2024, that is not counting deaths in rural areas which might go unreported.

Unfortunately, because of their overpowered and understandably terrifying nature, they are also one of the most misunderstood reptiles in the world.

sections.heading: A Master of Land and Water
sections.content:
Well adapted to life underwater, as evidenced by interesting evolutionary features such as a third transparent eyelid which protects their eyes as they swim underwater, or elongated scutes on their tail in order to improve their movement underwater, crocodiles are no doubt deadly underwater.

What makes them terrifying to humans is that not only are they well adapted to the swamp, they are also just as lethal on land. It can both run and swim up to 18 miles per hour, matching the pace of an average full grown man’s sprint, and three times faster than the average human’s swim.

image.caption: (Reid Park Zoo, Crocodile Third Eyelid)

sections.heading: Hidden Intelligence and Social Bonds
sections.content:
Although deadly predators, many people overlook that crocodiles are evidenced to be incredibly intelligent, and form complex social systems.

Crocodiles have been documented to communicate even before they hatch, vocalizing when they are ready to hatch in order to summon their mother. After birth, the baby crocodiles will often stay with their mother for months, and communicate with the other crocodiles around them. This behavior is almost more similar to mammals than other reptiles.

image.caption: (Artist Conception of a Primitive Crocodile Fossil, Todd Marshall, National Geographic)

sections.heading: Complex Communication and 'Home' Instincts
sections.content:
There is a lot of current research on the existence of crocodile social systems, expanding on things we already know such as the existence of courtship and distress calls. One article from The University of Queensland in Australia has observed that crocodiles have distinct social systems where they split into communities. Perhaps evidence that the communication crocodiles learn comes from specific crocodile cultures, as it has been proven that baby crocodiles in captivity are capable of learning.

Furthermore, crocodiles may have a sense of home beyond just defending their territory. Studies found that crocodiles which were captured and relocated often swam thousands of miles to return to the same rivers where they were captured.

image.caption: (Baby crocodile carried by mother to water)

sections.heading: Reframing Fear
sections.content:
So yes. While it is true that we should be scared of saltwater crocodiles, and we definitely shouldn’t go wandering in a swamp that clearly says, “Danger! Crocodiles!” crocodiles likely suffer from the misfortune of simply looking very dangerous.

Other animals like mosquitoes have caused over a million deaths, as of 2024. That is 100,000% of what crocodiles cause, though because we are accustomed to mosquitoes, we are less scared of them.

This isn’t to say that you should go to the nearest swamp and befriend a crocodile, rather admire the fact that they are much more complex social creatures than we often give them credit for (from a distance…please).

title: Arizona's Hidden Past: 200 Million Years of Reptiles
author: Unknown
summary: While modern Arizona is known for its desert reptiles, 200 million years ago the land was a sprawling forest and seaway. Recent discoveries in the Petrified Forest National Park, including 'North America's oldest known pterosaur' and new Triassic reptile species, are shedding light on a diverse ancient ecosystem that thrived alongside dinosaurs, raising fascinating questions about reptile evolution and global connections.

sections.heading: From Desert Heat to Ancient Seaway
sections.content:
Arizona’s reptiles are known for a few things; sandy, dry, and hot. From the Gila Monster to the Diamondback Rattlesnake, Arizona’s reptiles fit into a specific archetype of desert life.

But 200 million years ago Arizona was home to forests and dinosaurs. 100 million years ago Arizona was a warm seaway, home to large aquatic creatures. Traces of these reptile family members, though long gone, are still found in Arizona today.

image.caption: (Petrified forest today)

sections.heading: A Graveyard of Giants
sections.content: Last summer, researchers in Arizona’s Petrified Forest National Park, which eons ago was a tall and sprawling forest before becoming the dry and arid desert it is today, discovered what may be “North America’s oldest known pterosaur”.

image.caption: (Petrified forest 208-228 million years ago)

sections.heading: Pterosaurs and Armored Crocodiles
sections.content:
The pterosaur was a winged reptile, one of the first vertebrates (excluding flies, bees, etc) to fly alongside dinosaurs in the period.

But that wasn’t all that was found in the Petrified Forest. The Forest is a graveyard of trees, older than 200 million years, it is unsurprising that in such a historic site a plethora of other old Mesozoic and Jurassic wonders would be discovered. The bonebed was able to capture both species which had been thriving for a long time (such as the infamous armored crocodile), and new ones which had just evolved (such as frogs) and how they may have lived alongside one another.

image.caption: (Armored crocodile rendition)

sections.heading: New Species and Global Connections
sections.content:
Besides the new species of pterosaur that was named this summer; a new species of Triassic reptile, called *Akidostropheus oligos*, was also discovered. Hypothesized to have lived in swampy ponds or small rivers, this tanystropheid has an unusually long and thin neck.

As we uncover more about the reptiles that lived here millions of years before we did, we can understand how this may connect to modern day reptiles living in terrariums and crawling around backyards today. The fossils of an ancient turtle, with spike-like armor and its similarity to the oldest known turtle uncovered in Germany, might bring new ideas about how Arizona and European turtles could be connected.

This raises questions about how they could have gotten there, as turtles move notoriously slow.
But what doesn’t move notoriously slow?
The field of paleontology.

title: Climate Change and Its Impact on Florida's Reptiles
author: Irina Tabacila
summary: Climate change threatens Florida’s diverse reptile species, affecting their reproduction, habitats due to sea-level rise, food sources, and nesting success from increased storms.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.content: Florida's diverse reptile species, from the American alligator (Alligator mississippiensis) to the green sea turtle (Chelonia mydas), play essential roles in the state's ecosystems. Unfortunately, climate change threatens these species, affecting their habitats, behaviors, and even their survival.

sections.heading: Rising Temperatures and Reproduction
sections.content: Florida's warming climate has profound effects on reptile reproduction, especially for species like sea turtles, whose egg incubation temperature determines hatchlings' sex. Warmer sands are producing more female hatchlings, which can disrupt population balance and affect future generations.

image.caption: Warmer sands are causing a significant bias toward female sea turtle hatchlings.

sections.heading: Sea-Level Rise and Habitat Loss
sections.content: With rising sea levels, coastal habitats like mangroves and marshes, crucial for species such as the American crocodile (Crocodylus acutus), are at risk. As saltwater intrudes, these reptiles lose nesting and foraging grounds, pushing them inland.

sections.heading: Altered Food Webs
sections.content: Reptiles play critical roles in Florida's food webs, but changing climate patterns impact their food sources. The gopher tortoise (Gopherus polyphemus) is a keystone species, but shifts in rainfall and temperature reduce vegetation availability, affecting it and the 300+ species relying on its burrows.

sections.heading: Increased Storms and Nesting Disruption
sections.content: More intense hurricanes due to climate change have devastating effects on coastal reptiles like loggerhead sea turtles (Caretta caretta), whose nests are often destroyed by storms. Frequent storms reduce hatchling success rates and challenge population recovery.

sections.heading: Taking Action
sections.content: To protect Florida's reptiles, conservation efforts must address habitat preservation, especially for nesting sites, and climate adaptation strategies. Restoring and safeguarding freshwater and coastal habitats can help reptiles adapt to a rapidly changing environment.

title: Reptiles of Ontario: The Province's Scaly Residents
author: Darwin Li
summary: Discover the diverse range of fascinating snake, turtle, and lizard species that thrive in Ontario, Canada, despite the province's cooler climate.

sections.heading: Introduction: Ontario's Diverse Scaly Residents
sections.content: Ontario, Canada's most populous province, is home to a diverse range of wildlife, including some fascinating reptiles. Despite the province's cooler climate, a variety of snake, turtle, and lizard species thrive in Ontario's diverse habitats. Let's take a closer look at some of the scaly residents of Ontario.

sections.heading: 1. The Eastern Massasauga Rattlesnake
sections.content:
Scientific Name: Sistrurus catenatus

The Eastern Massasauga Rattlesnake is Ontario's **only venomous snake** and is considered a species at risk. Found primarily in the Georgian Bay area, this shy and reclusive snake prefers wetlands, prairies, and forests. Despite its fearsome reputation, it is not aggressive and will typically avoid human contact.

Conservation Status: Threatened
Fun Fact: The Massasauga's rattle, made of keratin, produces its famous warning sound when vibrated.

image.caption: The Eastern Massasauga Rattlesnake is a threatened species, primarily found in the Georgian Bay area.

sections.heading: 2. The Painted Turtle
sections.content:
Scientific Name: Chrysemys picta

The Painted Turtle is the **most widespread native turtle** in Ontario, easily recognized by its smooth, olive-colored shell and brightly colored markings. These turtles are often seen basking on logs in ponds, marshes, and slow-moving rivers throughout the province.

Conservation Status: Special Concern
Fun Fact: Painted Turtles can survive in frozen ponds by slowing their metabolism and absorbing oxygen through their skin.

image.caption: Painted Turtles are a common sight, often basking on logs in slow-moving water bodies.

sections.heading: 3. The Five-lined Skink
sections.content:
Scientific Name: Plestiodon fasciatus

The **Five-lined Skink is Ontario's only native lizard**, found in the warm, rocky areas of the province, particularly in the southern regions and along the shores of Lake Erie. Juveniles are easily identified by their bright blue tails, which fade with age.

Conservation Status: Special Concern
Fun Fact: When threatened, the skink can detach its tail to distract predators while it escapes.

image.caption: Juvenile Five-lined Skinks are known for their distinctive bright blue tails.

sections.heading: 4. The Northern Watersnake
sections.content:
Scientific Name: Nerodia sipedon

The Northern Watersnake is commonly found near lakes, rivers, and marshes throughout Ontario. Although often mistaken for the venomous Massasauga due to its aggressive behavior when threatened, the watersnake is **non-venomous** and poses no harm to humans.

Conservation Status: Least Concern
Fun Fact: Northern Watersnakes are excellent swimmers and can often be seen hunting for fish and amphibians in the water.

image.caption: The non-venomous Northern Watersnake is an aggressive-looking but harmless aquatic species.

sections.heading: 5. The Blanding's Turtle
sections.content:
Scientific Name: Emydoidea blandingii

Blanding's Turtles are easily recognized by their high-domed shell and **bright yellow throat**. Preferring shallow wetlands, these turtles are known for their long lifespan, often living for over 70 years. Unfortunately, habitat loss has put this species at risk.

Conservation Status: Threatened
Fun Fact: Blanding's Turtles are sometimes referred to as the “smiling turtle” due to the shape of their mouth.

image.caption: The Blanding's Turtle is known for its distinctive yellow throat and long lifespan.

sections.heading: Conservation Efforts and How You Can Help
sections.content:
Ontario's reptiles face numerous challenges, including habitat loss, road mortality, and climate change. Conservation efforts are vital to protecting these unique species and ensuring they remain a part of Ontario's natural heritage.

Get Involved:

  • **Join Citizen Science Projects:** Participate in programs like the Reptile Map Project to help monitor and protect local reptile populations.
  • **Support Conservation Organizations:** Donate or volunteer with organizations dedicated to wildlife conservation in Ontario.
  • **Be a Responsible Visitor:** When exploring Ontario's natural areas, respect wildlife and habitats, and report any illegal activities.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.content: Ontario's reptiles are an integral part of the province's biodiversity, offering a unique glimpse into the resilience and adaptability of nature. Whether you're an experienced naturalist or just beginning to explore Ontario's wildlife, taking the time to learn about these fascinating creatures can deepen your connection to the natural world and inspire efforts to protect it.

title: Reptile Conservation in Nigeria: Preserving a Vital Piece of Biodiversity
author: Razi Taraji
summary: Nigeria is home to an extraordinary array of reptiles. This post examines the diversity of its species and the critical conservation efforts required to protect them from increasing threats like habitat loss and hunting.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.content: Nigeria, a country rich in cultural diversity and natural beauty, is also home to an extraordinary array of reptile species. From the lush rainforests of the south to the arid savannas of the north, Nigeria's diverse ecosystems provide habitat for some of the most unique reptiles in Africa. However, like many other parts of the world, these reptiles are facing increasing threats, making conservation efforts more important than ever.

sections.heading: The African Rock Python
sections.content:
Scientific Name: Python sebae

One of the largest snake species in the world, the African Rock Python can be found in a variety of habitats across Nigeria, from savannas to forests. Despite its size and power, this python faces threats from habitat destruction and hunting.

image.caption: The African Rock Python, one of the largest snake species in the world, is found in various habitats across Nigeria.

sections.heading: The Nile Monitor
sections.content:
Scientific Name: Varanus niloticus

This large, agile lizard is commonly found near rivers and lakes. Known for its impressive swimming ability, the Nile Monitor plays a key role in controlling pest populations but is often hunted for its skin.

image.caption: The Nile Monitor, a large and agile lizard, plays a crucial role in controlling pest populations in Nigeria.

sections.heading: The West African Crocodile
sections.content:
Scientific Name: Crocodylus suchus

Once considered the same species as the Nile Crocodile, the West African Crocodile inhabits freshwater habitats across Nigeria. It is a keystone species, crucial for maintaining the balance of aquatic ecosystems.

image.caption: The West African Crocodile, a keystone species in Nigeria's freshwater ecosystems.

sections.heading: The Dwarf Crocodile
sections.content:
Scientific Name: Osteolaemus tetraspis

This small and secretive crocodile is primarily found in the rainforests of southern Nigeria. It is critically endangered due to habitat loss and hunting for bushmeat.

image.caption: The critically endangered Dwarf Crocodile, found in the rainforests of southern Nigeria.

sections.heading: The African Helmeted Turtle
sections.content:
Scientific Name: Pelomedusa subrufa

This common but fascinating turtle species is often seen in ponds and rivers. It plays an important role in the aquatic food chain but faces threats from pollution and waterway destruction.

image.caption: The African Helmeted Turtle is commonly found in ponds and rivers across Nigeria.

sections.heading: Threats to Reptiles in Nigeria
sections.content:
Despite their ecological importance, reptiles in Nigeria are under significant threat from various human activities:
  • Habitat Destruction: Deforestation, agricultural expansion, and urban development are rapidly reducing their natural habitats.
  • Illegal Hunting and Trade: Many reptiles are hunted for their skins, meat, or for use in traditional medicine.
  • Pollution: Water pollution from industrial waste and runoff is contaminating aquatic habitats.
  • Climate Change: Changes in temperature and rainfall patterns are affecting reproductive cycles.

image.caption: Habitat destruction, such as deforestation, poses a significant threat to Nigeria's reptile populations.

sections.heading: Conservation Efforts in Nigeria
sections.content:
Conservation efforts in Nigeria are vital to protect and preserve these unique reptile species. Key initiatives include:

  • **Protected Areas:** Establishing and maintaining national parks and wildlife reserves.
  • **Community Engagement:** Programs that educate and involve local communities in conservation efforts.
  • **Research and Monitoring:** Conducting research on reptile populations and threats to develop effective strategies.
  • **Legislation and Enforcement:** Strengthening and enforcing laws against illegal hunting and trade.
  • **Education and Awareness:** Raising public awareness about the importance of reptiles.

image.caption: Conservation efforts in Nigeria focus on protecting natural habitats and engaging local communities.

sections.heading: How You Can Help
sections.content:
As individuals, there are several ways to contribute to reptile conservation in Nigeria:
  • Support Conservation Organizations.
  • Reduce Your Impact (minimize pollution and support sustainable practices).
  • Advocate for Conservation.
  • Educate Others.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.content: Reptiles are an integral part of Nigeria's rich biodiversity, playing vital roles in ecosystems and cultural heritage. However, without concerted conservation efforts, many of these species could disappear. By protecting reptiles, we are also safeguarding the health of our ecosystems and preserving the natural world for future generations.

title: Lizards in Southwest Native American Culture
author: Alyssa Lu
summary: For many Native Southwest tribes, lizards and their kin, like the Horned Toad and Gila Monster, hold deep spiritual value, symbolizing healing, protection, and survival.

sections.heading: Lizards: More Than Backyard Accessories
sections.content:
If you're ever taking a stroll on a dirt path in Phoenix at night, you can sometimes hear a faint twitchy scurrying sound around your footsteps. This is usually a lizard; one of the cold-blooded creatures who adore the Southwest heat.

While modern residents view them as simple backyard accessories, for the Navajo and other Native Southwest tribes, they have much more spiritual value.

image.caption: A 2014-04 Seedpot with Lizard and Horned Toad Warriors Hunting Ants.

sections.heading: Symbol of Healing and Rebirth
sections.content:
In one story, Coyote encounters a group of lizards sledding down a rock. After the lizards revive Coyote following an accident, the animal gains recognition for its spiritual significance.

Being one of the rare land-bound animals that can **regenerate cartilage**, it's not a surprise that lizards represent **healing, survival, and rebirth**.

sections.heading: The Venomous Gila Monster
sections.content: The Gila Monster, which unlike most lizards is venomous, has stories about **resurrecting warriors** who fell in battle. Their powerful presence contributes to their spiritual standing within tribal narratives.

image.caption: A picture of a Gila Monster, known for its venom and its role in stories of resurrection.

sections.heading: The Horned Toad: Grandfather of Protection
sections.content:
One of the most important reptiles in Navajo culture is the Horned Toad, who is also called **Grandfather (Cheii)**. One Navajo story shows that when Lightning challenged Horned Toad, the toad averted the attacks each time using songs and eventually defeated Lightning with its spikes. Thus, his songs are used for **protection**.

Because of its array of spikes, the horned toad is a powerful symbol of protection—not only of one's physical body, but also one's mind, spirit, and emotions, due to its proximity to the ground.

image.caption: A picture of a Horned lizard, or 'Grandfather,' respected as a symbol of protection.

sections.heading: The Finger Debate (Pomo Tribe)
sections.content: Though not in Arizona, the Pomo tribe tells another story about Lizard and Coyote, where the two had a throw down to decide whether humans should have fingers or paws, like Coyote. Thankfully, Lizard won, giving humans their dexterity.

sections.heading: Threats to a Sacred Population
sections.content:
With temperatures in the Southwest rising, and Arizona's pesticides, population, and asphalt spreading, Gila monsters, lizards, and Horned toads have found their once bountiful population decreasing. The Horned lizards that old residents of Tucson and Catalina Foothills used to see out and about are 'essentially extinct in Phoenix, outside mountain parks'.

Even if we don't have much place for lizards in our rapidly expanding society, that does not mean we should not respect them. We should dread the night we walk outside and find that we suddenly can't seem to spot those familiar little twigs scurrying around in the crevices they used to.

title: The Role of Reptiles: Maintaining Earth’s Biodiversity
author: Jacob Shi
summary: Reptiles have fulfilled an integral role in maintaining biodiversity for 320 million years, serving as predators, prey, pollinators, and environmental bioindicators.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.content: Appearing on Earth 320 million years ago, reptiles continue to fulfill an integral role maintaining biodiversity. Their impact is evident, with over 12,000 recorded reptile species contributing to the balance of ecosystems across the globe. This article provides a brief overview of the benefits that reptiles confer to ecosystems.

sections.heading: Role as Predators and Keystone Species
sections.content:
Reptiles act as **predators** that help control the population of their prey, which includes insects, birds, and small mammals. As such, they mitigate agricultural and habitat damage caused by uncontrolled pests and an overpopulation of prey species.

Reptiles can also be a **keystone species**, defined as one disproportionately influential to its environment relative to its population size. A prime example is the Gopher Tortoise native to the southeastern United States.

image.caption: The Gopher Tortoise is a keystone species, digging burrows used as shelter by over 300 other species.

sections.heading: Role as Prey Species
sections.content: Conversely, reptiles can be a **prey species**, especially when growing up. In this way, they contribute to the flow of energy within an ecosystem and food web, transferring energy up the chain to larger animals.

sections.heading: Role as Pollinators
sections.content: Although uncommon, reptiles also act as a **pollinator species**, enabling the growth of plants and trees. For instance, the Noronha skink from Brazil drinks nectar from flowers. In doing so, the anthers and stigmas of the flower make contact with their skin, where pollen can stick. As they move across flowers and trees, they deposit the pollen and may pollinate the flower.

sections.heading: Role as Bioindicators
sections.content: Reptiles, being **bioindicators**, contribute to our understanding of habitats; they can be a factor in determining the quality of their particular habitat. Reptiles are ectotherms and are sensitive to their environment, so a change in reptile behavior can mark a form of damage. Similarly, they can be used to assess environmental pollution and contaminants which bioaccumulate based on variations in population.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.content: Overall, reptiles provide numerous ecological benefits. They contribute to ecosystems through their role as predator, prey, pollinator, and indicator species. Regardless of the specific species and mechanism, reptiles bring immense value to supporting biodiversity.

title: The Role of Native Green Anoles and Invasive Brown Anoles in Florida's Ecosystem Dynamics
author: Irina Tabacila and Dean Zacharis
summary: The arrival of the invasive brown anole has created complex ecosystem dynamics in Florida, forcing native green anoles to adapt their habitat and compete fiercely for resources.

sections.heading: Introduction: Lizards as Ecosystem Indicators
sections.content: Lizards contribute to the balance of ecosystems as both predator and prey. They help control insect populations, which prevents overpopulation and the spread of diseases, and they are a food source for birds, mammals, and other reptiles. This linkage between native green anoles and invasive brown anoles exemplifies the subtleties regarding Florida ecosystem dynamics, and has major implications for biodiversity.

sections.heading: The Invasion of the Brown Anole
sections.content:
Green anoles (Anolis carolinensis) are the only species of anole native to Florida. The arrival of brown anoles (Anolis sagrei) from Cuba and the Bahamas in the mid-20th century, likely through cargo shipments, has disrupted this balance.

Brown anoles have spread rapidly, often **outcompeting native green anoles for food and habitat** due to their aggressive nature and adaptability. This has led to their dominance in many parts of Florida.

sections.heading: Competition in Action (A Personal Encounter)
sections.content:
One morning, while volunteering at Halifax Health, I took a walk through their garden. I spotted a green anole on a low branch hunting ants with quick, precise movements. As I watched, I noticed a brown anole nearby that started to interfere with the green anole's hunt by going for the same food source.

This competition highlights Florida's ecosystems, where native and invasive species compete for resources.

image.caption: An invasive Brown Anole observed competing for food in a Florida garden.

sections.heading: Ecological Consequences of Resource Competition
sections.content: This competition has forced green anoles to higher perches, limiting their range and access to resources, which has significant ecological consequences. This change affects their behavior, feeding patterns, and overall chance of survival in the near future.

image.caption: A Native Green Anole showcasing its vibrant color, a species being pushed to higher habitats.

sections.heading: Conclusion: Preserving Native Populations
sections.content: While brown anoles still play a role in the ecosystem, the protection and support of green anole populations are essential. As the native species, green anoles are integral to maintaining Florida's biodiversity and ecological balance. It is crucial to address the challenges posed by invasive brown anoles to ensure the survival and prosperity of green anoles, thereby preserving the intricate dynamics of Florida's ecosystems.

title: Youth and Communities Helping Turtles and Protecting Wetlands
author: Darwin Li
summary: Learn why turtles are considered 'wildlife heroes' for their vital role in cleaning water and spreading biodiversity, and why community action is crucial as 75% of global turtles face extinction.

sections.heading: Introduction: Turtles are Wildlife Heroes
sections.content: About 70% of fish and wildlife across Eastern North America depend on freshwater turtles to clean water, cycle nutrients, and spread seeds & biodiversity. However, 75% of the world’s turtles are in jeopardy of becoming extinct and all of Canada’s are listed as Species at Risk.

image.caption: Freshwater habitats across North America rely heavily on the presence of turtle species.

sections.heading: The Keystone Role of Turtles
sections.content:
Turtles are a **keystone species**—they play an important role in keeping an ecosystem functioning. They maintain the health of our wetlands by consuming the carcasses of dead fish and animals, which removes harmful bacteria; and they also eat plants and spread seeds to grow new fish nurseries, moose habitats and wetland areas.

Turtles also have cultural and spiritual importance for some Indigenous cultures. All of Canada’s and 3/4 of the U.S.A’s and the world’s turtles are endangered, and it can take turtles up to 60 years for a turtle to replace themself once in nature.

sections.heading: Conclusion: Protecting Our Best Biodiversity Agents
sections.content: Without turtles – our best cleaning crews and biodiversity agents – we would not be able to enjoy nature in the ways we can today. Community and youth involvement in conservation efforts are vital to ensuring the survival of these species and the continued health of our wetlands.
